Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CEDAR--A Focused Study of Sustained Upward Vertical Winds in the Auroral Zone
Award.AbstractNarration: The investigators will use data from a multi-instrument observational campaign centered on Poker Flat Research Range near Fairbanks, AK to study the phenomenon of sustained upward vertical winds (SUVW) in the thermosphere that are associated with the soft particle precipitation of auroral activity. These winds have speeds in excess of 15 meters per second and appear continuously upward over several hours. They are generally preceded by a period of downward winds with speeds of 20 to 30 m/s. Far from being an intriguing curiosity, vertical winds are important to understanding the complex dynamic behavior of the upper atmosphere. Vertical winds in the thermosphere are responsible for vertical mass transport, disrupting stratification and changing the local composition, which can lead to changes in the overall thermal budget. Understanding the underlying source of these sustained vertical upward winds will enable a prediction of the global distribution of their occurrence and their impact on thermospheric dynamics. The study will take advantage of a critical mass of key instruments in the auroral zone in central Alaska that will produce comprehensive data sets to characterize the auroral input and large scale thermospheric conditions leading to the sustained upward vertical wind events. The primary instruments for observing vertical winds will be a set of three imaging Fabry-Perot interferometers (FPI), located at Poker Flat, Fort Yukon and Eagle, AK and dedicated to high-cadence zenith measurements. The contextual instruments include the Poker Flat Incoherent Scatter Radar (PFISR), a set of four scanning Doppler imagers (SDI) at Poker Flat, Gakona, Toolik Field Station, and Kaktovik, AK, all-sky cameras and meridian spectrographs at Poker Flat and remote observing sites. The broader impacts of this work will be the training and educational opportunities for undergraduates in technical research by participating in the analysis of the data obtained by the zenith FPI instruments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project outcome report AGS-1243077

The scientific purpose of the award was to observe the vertical winds of the auroral region simultaneously from three locations separated by about 150 km (90 miles). Such winds have been seen previously to be quite large, in excess of 30 to 60 ms-1, during times of soft electron precipitation that was capable of producing only oxygen red line emission (630-nm). Harder particle precipitation would produce a mixture of colors including that of green and blue but these periods are generally not associated with any significant vertical wind activity. What is especially puzzling is that these periods of large sustained? upward vertical winds ?(SUVW) ?are seen to ?persist? over periods as long as three to six hours in correlation with the periods of continued enhanced red line emissions.

This award supported the deployment of a modified Fabry-Perot interferometer (FPI) to Eagle AK to observe only in the zenith the neutral winds of the air layer between 200 and 300 km (120 miles to 180 km).? Also part of this FPI network are two other FPI observatories located at Ft. Yukon,AK, and at Poker Flat, AK that are able to observe in any direction. 

?The goal for this network was to obtain simultaneous data on the SUVW phenomenon for all three stations so to see if there is any indication of a wave front propagation of the onset and duration of SUVW events. Also of interest was the possible latitudinal and longitudinal dependence of SUVW occurrence and magnitude.

Possible sources of contamination toward the production of possible SUVW events have been considered but the various tests made possible using the extensive optical diagnostics available at Poker Flat (suite of all-sky imagers, meridian spectrographs) have indicated the lack of any significant correlation. A reasonable interpretation of this result suggests that possible explanations such as optical scattering of red-shifted light into the instrument field of view or spectral contamination by nitrogen first positive band emission may be discounted. 

Thus, at the present time, the data from other optical instruments as well as the Poker Flat incoherent scatter radar data are being used to compare the magnitude and timing of the observed ?SUVW episode with other geophysical parameters, including variations in auroral electrojet currents determined from magnetometer data, estimates of Joule heating determined using combined SDI and radar plasma drift data, and the location and intensity of auroral electron precipitation. In the case of Poker Flat and Fort Yukon, data for SUVW ?periods will be compared with the long-pulse AMISR data, looking in particular at high altitude plasma upwelling. The results of these comparisons will help support or refute hypotheses of whether the measured upwelling is a product of thermal expansion due to localized heating, or is due to a more complicated plasma interaction, including upwelling of O+ ions along the geomagnetic field line.

These comparisons, either individually or grouped, will form the basis of journal articles, ??which ?are? expected? to ?be started ?within the next year?. A ?publication is bei?n??g? pr?epared by the lead PI, Dr. Don Hampton,? ?with John Meriwether as a co-author ?for the Journal of Geophysical Research Space Physics highlighting? the multi-station SUVW phenomenon.?
